recipes.name: Traditional Indian Rice Pudding (Kheer)
ingredients: Optional: Fresh rose petals for garnish
directions: Step 1: Rinse the Basmati rice thoroughly under cold water until the water runs clear. Soak the rice in enough water to cover it completely for 30 minutes.

Step 2: In a deep, heavy-bottomed pot or saucepan, combine the whole milk, sweetened condensed milk, and sugar. Bring the mixture to a rolling boil over medium heat, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.

Step 3: Drain the soaked rice and add it to the boiling milk mixture. Reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and simmer for 45-60 minutes, or until the rice is cooked through, the milk has thickened, and the volume has reduced by approximately half. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and scorching.
Step 4: Add the blanched, slivered almonds, raisins, and ground cardamom to the kheer. Continue to simmer for another 5 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld.
Step 5: Remove the pot from the heat and stir in the saffron threads. Gently mix until the kheer is evenly tinted with the saffron color.
Step 6: Allow the kheer to cool to room temperature. Once cooled, cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, or preferably overnight, to chill thoroughly.
Step 7: Serve the chilled kheer in individual bowls, garnished with fresh rose petals (optional).
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of creamy Kheer in a rustic earthenware bowl, garnished with slivered almonds, plump raisins, and saffron threads. Use a shallow depth of field to focus sharply on the rice pudding's texture, blurring the background which includes a brass serving spoon and a sprinkle of cardamom. Soft, warm, natural lighting should highlight the creamy white color and glistening textures.  Incorporate a dark, textured backdrop to create a mood of rich indulgence and tradition.  Garnish with a few fresh rose petals for a touch of elegance.

recipes.name: Creamy Basmati Rice Kheer
ingredients: 1 tablespoon rose water or kewra water (optional)
directions: Step 1: Rinse the basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Soak the rice in enough water for 15-20 minutes.
Step 2: (Optional) Blanch the almonds: Boil water in a small pan, add almonds, cover, and set aside for 30 minutes. Peel and slice the almonds.
Step 3: In a heavy-bottomed pan or pot, bring the whole milk to a boil over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Step 4: In a small bowl, warm 1 tablespoon of milk and infuse the saffron strands in it. Set aside.
Step 5: Drain the soaked rice and add it to the boiling milk. Mix well and simmer uncovered over low heat until the rice is half-cooked.
Step 6: Add sugar and mix well. Continue to simmer, stirring occasionally, until the rice is almost fully cooked.
Step 7: Add ground green cardamom, sliced almonds, chopped cashews, and chopped pistachios. Mix well.
Step 8: Add the saffron-infused milk and mix again. Continue cooking over low heat until the kheer thickens and the rice is fully cooked.
Step 9: Once the rice is cooked and the kheer has thickened, remove from heat. Scrape any milk solids from the sides of the pan and incorporate them into the kheer.
Step 10: Stir in the golden raisins and optionally, rose water or kewra water.
Step 11: Pour the kheer into individual serving bowls and serve hot, warm, or chilled. Refrigerate leftovers in a closed container for up to 2 days.

recipes.name: Creamy Sabudana Kheer (Tapioca Pearl Pudding)
ingredients: ¼ cup sugar (or raw sugar), adjust to taste
½ teaspoon green cardamom powder (or 4-5 green cardamoms, crushed)
directions: Step 1: Rinse the sabudana pearls under cold water until the water runs clear.
Step 2: In a thick-bottomed pan or saucepan, combine the rinsed sabudana pearls and water.
Step 3: Cover the pan and let the sabudana soak for 15-20 minutes.
Step 4: Place the pan on the stovetop over medium heat.
Step 5: Meanwhile, gently warm the milk in a separate saucepan. Do not boil.
Step 6: After 4-5 minutes of cooking the sabudana, add the warm milk to the pan.
Step 7: Add the sugar and green cardamom powder. Simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until the sabudana pearls are soft and translucent, stirring frequently to prevent sticking.
Step 8: Remove the pan from the heat and stir in the cashews and raisins. Taste and add more sugar if needed.
Step 9: Adjust the consistency of the kheer by adding more milk if needed. Keep in mind that it will thicken as it cools.
Step 10: Garnish with saffron strands before serving.

recipes.name: Classic Indian Rice Pudding (Kheer)
directions: Step 1: Rinse the basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear. In a medium saucepan, combine the rinsed rice and 2 cups of water. Bring to a boil over medium heat, then reduce heat and simmer for 5-6 minutes, or until the rice is about one-quarter cooked.
Step 2: Drain the partially cooked rice in a fine-mesh colander.
Step 3: In a heavy-bottomed saucepan or pot, bring the milk and green cardamom pods to a boil over medium heat.  Stir occasionally to prevent scorching.

Step 4: Add the drained rice to the boiling milk. Reduce the heat to low and simmer gently for 30-40 minutes, or until the rice is very soft and the milk has thickened considerably. Stir frequently to prevent the rice from sticking to the bottom of the pot and to ensure even cooking.

Step 5: Once the rice is cooked and the milk is thick, add the granulated sugar, blanched slivered almonds, ground cardamom, and ground nutmeg. Stir constantly and cook for another 5 minutes, allowing the sugar to dissolve and the flavors to meld.
Step 6: Remove the kheer from the heat and stir in the rose water.
Step 7: Serve the kheer warm or chilled in dessert bowls. Garnish with additional slivered almonds, if desired.

recipes.name: Sabudana Kheer (Tapioca Pudding)
directions: Step 1: Rinse the tapioca pearls under cold running water until the water runs clear. Drain well.

Step 2: In a medium saucepan, combine the rinsed tapioca pearls, milk, and water. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat, then reduce the heat to low and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the tapioca pearls are translucent and cooked through (about 15-20 minutes).
Step 3: Add the sugar and stir until it dissolves completely.
Step 4: Stir in the crushed cardamom pods and saffron threads.
Step 5: Drain the soaked raisins and add them to the kheer.
Step 6: Continue to simmer for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the kheer thickens to a creamy consistency.
Step 7: Pour the kheer into serving bowls and garnish with the slivered almonds.
Step 8: Serve warm or chilled.

recipes.name: Vermicelli Pudding (Seviyan Kheer)
directions: Step 1: Heat the ghee in a heavy-bottomed pot or pan over medium heat. Add the cloves (if using) and fry for 2-3 seconds.
Step 2: Add the broken vermicelli and roast over low to medium-low heat, stirring constantly, until golden brown.
Step 3: Reduce heat to low and slowly pour in the milk, mixing well. Simmer, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking, until the milk comes to a boil.
Step 4: Add the sugar and stir until dissolved. Add the saffron strands, almond slivers, and cashews (if using). Mix well.
Step 5: Add the cardamom powder and rose petals (if using). Cook for 4-5 minutes, or until the vermicelli is cooked through and the kheer has thickened to a creamy consistency.
Step 6: Remove from heat and stir in the golden raisins. Check for sweetness and add more sugar if needed.
Step 7: Serve hot, warm, or chilled. Garnish with chopped nuts or dried rose petals before serving.

recipes.name: Creamy Almond Kheer (Badam Kheer)
ingredients: ¼ to ⅓ cup milk (for grinding)
directions: Step 1: Soak the almonds: Rinse ½ cup whole almonds and place them in a bowl. Pour ½ cup hot boiling water over the almonds, cover, and set aside for 30-40 minutes.
Step 2: Blanch and prepare almonds: Drain the water and peel the soaked almonds. Thinly slice 3-4 almonds for garnish and set aside. Place the remaining blanched almonds in a grinder jar.

Step 3: Grind almond paste: Add 5 tablespoons of sugar (or to taste) and the seeds from 4 green cardamom pods to the grinder jar.  Add ¼ to ⅓ cup of milk. Grind to a smooth paste, ensuring no coarse particles remain.
Step 4: Heat milk: In a large pan, heat 2 ½ cups of milk over low flame. Bring the milk to a gentle boil, stirring occasionally to prevent scorching.
Step 5: Infuse saffron: Add 10-12 saffron strands to the boiling milk and stir. Simmer for 3-4 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Step 6: Combine almond paste: Add the ground almond paste to the simmering milk and mix well. Bring the kheer to a boil, stirring continuously.

Step 7: Finish and serve: Once the kheer comes to a boil, turn off the heat. Scrape any milk solids from the sides of the pan and incorporate them into the kheer. Serve hot, warm, or chilled, garnished with sliced almonds and a few strands of saffron.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of the ingredients arranged on a table: whole almonds, a bowl of hot water, sugar, green cardamom pods, milk, saffron strands, and sliced almonds for garnish.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: half a cup of whole almonds, hot water for soaking, five tablespoons of sugar, four green cardamom pods, two and a half cups of milk, saffron strands, and some sliced almonds for garnish.

scenes.image_prompt: Almonds soaking in a bowl of hot water.
scenes.voice_over: First, soak half a cup of almonds in hot water for 30-40 minutes. This will soften them and make them easier to peel.

scenes.image_prompt: Hands peeling blanched almonds. A few sliced almonds are set aside on a small plate.
scenes.voice_over: Drain the water and peel the almonds. Set aside a few thinly sliced almonds for garnish.

scenes.image_prompt: A grinder jar with blanched almonds, sugar, cardamom pods, and milk.
scenes.voice_over: In a grinder, add the blanched almonds, five tablespoons of sugar, seeds from four green cardamom pods, and half to three-quarters of a cup of milk. Grind to a smooth paste.

scenes.image_prompt: Milk heating in a large pan on a stovetop over a low flame.
scenes.voice_over: In a pan, heat two and a half cups of milk over low heat. Bring it to a gentle boil, stirring occasionally.

scenes.image_prompt: Saffron strands being added to the simmering milk.
scenes.voice_over: Add 10-12 saffron strands to the boiling milk. Let it simmer for 3-4 minutes to infuse the color and flavor.

scenes.image_prompt: Almond paste being added to the saffron-infused milk and stirred continuously.
scenes.voice_over: Add the ground almond paste to the milk and mix well. Bring the kheer to a boil, stirring continuously to prevent sticking.

scenes.image_prompt: Finished kheer being transferred to serving bowls and garnished with sliced almonds and saffron strands.
scenes.voice_over: Once it boils, turn off the heat. Scrape down any milk solids from the sides. Serve hot, warm, or chilled, garnished with sliced almonds and saffron. Enjoy your Creamy Almond Kheer!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use full-fat milk.
Adjust the sugar quantity according to your preference.
Soaking the almonds makes them easier to peel and grind into a smooth paste.

recipes.name: Rajgira Kheer (Amaranth Pudding)
ingredients: ¼ cup sliced cashews or blanched almonds
directions: Step 1: Rinse the amaranth grains in a fine-mesh sieve.
Step 2: Combine the rinsed amaranth and water in a pressure cooker. Stir well.
Step 3: Pressure cook on medium heat for 3 whistles (or 9-10 minutes). Allow the pressure to release naturally.
Step 4: Add the milk to the pressure cooker.
Step 5: Place the cooker on the stovetop over low heat. Stir the milk and cooked amaranth mixture well. Simmer for 6-7 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Step 6: Add the sugar and stir. Continue simmering for 2 minutes.
Step 7: Add the sliced cashews/almonds, cardamom powder, and rose petals (if using). Stir well.
Step 8: Serve the Rajgira Kheer hot, warm, or chilled. Garnish with saffron strands or additional nuts before serving.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of Rajgira Kheer in a rustic, earthenware bowl.  The creamy, textured pudding should be garnished with a few cashews and rose petals. Use soft, diffused natural light to highlight the warm tones of the kheer and the nut garnishes. A shallow depth of field, focusing on the center of the bowl, should blur the textured background of a wooden table.  Incorporate a vintage silver spoon placed subtly beside the bowl. Aim for a warm, inviting, and comforting mood.

video_script.title: Rajgira Kheer (Amaranth Pudding) - A Healthy & Delicious Dessert

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a bowl of Rajgira Kheer garnished with chopped nuts and rose petals. The kheer should look creamy and inviting.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today we're making Rajgira Kheer, a delicious and healthy Indian dessert. It's creamy, nutty, and perfect for any occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Show all ingredients neatly arranged: ⅓ cup amaranth grains, 1 ½ cups water, 1 cup milk, ¼ cup sugar, ¼ cup nuts, ½ tsp cardamom powder, and rose petals.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: amaranth grains, water, milk, sugar, cashews or almonds, cardamom powder, and some rose petals for garnish.

scenes.image_prompt: Show amaranth being rinsed in a fine-mesh sieve under running water.
scenes.voice_over: Start by rinsing the amaranth grains thoroughly in a fine-mesh sieve until the water runs clear. This helps remove any impurities.

scenes.image_prompt: Amaranth and water being combined in a pressure cooker.
scenes.voice_over: Add the rinsed amaranth and water to a pressure cooker. Give it a good stir, and pressure cook on medium heat for 3 whistles, or about 9-10 minutes. Then, allow the pressure to release naturally.

scenes.image_prompt: Milk being added to the cooked amaranth in the pressure cooker.
scenes.voice_over: Once the pressure is released, add the milk to the cooker. Place it on the stovetop over low heat, and simmer for 6-7 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.

scenes.image_prompt: Sugar being added to the amaranth and milk mixture, then stirring.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add the sugar and stir well. Continue simmering for another 2 minutes until the sugar dissolves completely.

scenes.image_prompt: Cashews/almonds, cardamom powder, and rose petals being added to the kheer.
scenes.voice_over: Add the sliced cashews or almonds, cardamom powder, and rose petals. Stir gently to combine all the flavors.

scenes.image_prompt: Two bowls of Rajgira Kheer: one served hot, garnished with nuts, and another served chilled, garnished with saffron strands.
scenes.voice_over: Your Rajgira Kheer is ready! Serve it hot, warm, or chilled. Garnish with some extra nuts or saffron strands before serving. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use full-fat milk.
Adjust the amount of sugar according to your preference.
Soaking the cashews or almonds for 30 minutes before slicing will make them softer.
You can also add raisins, saffron strands, or chopped pistachios for extra flavor and texture.

recipes.name: Lauki Kheer (Bottle Gourd Pudding)
ingredients: 200 grams (1 cup) grated lauki (bottle gourd, dudhi, ghia, or opo squash)
directions: Step 1: Rinse, peel, and grate the lauki. You should have approximately 1 cup of grated lauki.
Step 2: In a thick-bottomed pan, heat the ghee or oil over medium heat.
Step 3: Add the grated lauki and sauté for 4-5 minutes, stirring frequently.
Step 4: Pour in the milk and stir well.
Step 5: Bring the mixture to a gentle simmer over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally to prevent scorching.
Step 6: Add the saffron strands and continue to simmer for 16-20 minutes, or until the milk has reduced slightly. Stir frequently and scrape down the sides of the pan.
Step 7: Add the sugar and stir until dissolved.
Step 8: Add the cardamom powder and cashews.
Step 9: Simmer for another 2-3 minutes.
Step 10: Remove from heat and stir in the rose water (if using).
Step 11: Garnish with the crushed rose petals (if using).
Step 12: Serve hot, warm, or chilled. The kheer will thicken as it cools.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of Lauki Kheer in a shallow, rustic clay bowl.  Garnish with saffron strands, chopped cashews, and rose petals.  Use soft, diffused natural light to highlight the creamy texture and pale green hue.  A dark, textured background will create contrast. Shallow depth of field, focusing sharply on the kheer’s surface, with a blurred background.  Aim for a warm, inviting mood evoking comfort and tradition.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a bowl of creamy Lauki Kheer garnished with chopped cashews and rose petals. The kheer should look inviting and decadent.

scenes.image_prompt: Show sautéing grated lauki in ghee/oil in a pan. Steam should be visible.
scenes.voice_over: Heat one tablespoon of ghee or oil in a thick-bottomed pan over medium heat. Add the grated lauki and sauté for 4-5 minutes, stirring frequently, until softened.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the milk being added into the pan. The pan should contain sauteed bottle gourd.
scenes.voice_over: Pour in 2 1/2 cups of full-fat milk and stir well. Bring the mixture to a gentle simmer over medium-low heat. Stir occasionally to prevent scorching.

scenes.image_prompt: Show saffron strands being added into the simmering milk and bottle gourd mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Add a pinch of saffron strands. Let it simmer for 16-20 minutes, stirring frequently, until the milk reduces slightly.  Don't forget to scrape down the sides to prevent sticking.

scenes.image_prompt: Show sugar, cardamom powder, and cashews being added into the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add 5 tablespoons of sugar, or to taste.  Also add half to three-quarters of a teaspoon of cardamom powder, and 12-15 cashews. Stir until the sugar dissolves completely.

recipes.name: Creamy Paneer Kheer (Indian Rice Pudding)
ingredients: ½ cup crumbled or grated paneer (about 50 grams)
½ teaspoon ground cardamom (or 3 to 4 green cardamom pods)
12 to 15 unsalted almonds, chopped or sliced
12 to 15 unsalted pistachios, chopped or sliced
12 to 15 unsalted cashews, chopped or sliced
1 to 1.5 teaspoons rose water or 1 drop rose essence (optional)
directions: Step 1: In a heavy-bottomed saucepan or wide-bottomed pan, heat the milk over medium-low heat. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Step 2: While the milk is heating, crumble or grate the paneer and set aside. If using refrigerated or frozen paneer, soak it in warm water before crumbling or grating.
Step 3: Grind the cardamom pods into a fine powder using a mortar and pestle. Chop the almonds, pistachios, and cashews.
Step 4: Once the milk comes to a gentle boil, reduce the heat to low and simmer for 5 to 6 minutes, or until slightly thickened. Stir occasionally.
Step 5: Add the sugar and continue to simmer for another 5 minutes, stirring until the sugar dissolves.
Step 6: Add the chopped almonds, pistachios, cashews, ground cardamom, and saffron (if using). Stir well and simmer for 1 to 2 minutes.
Step 7: Add the crumbled or grated paneer to the milk. Simmer for 1 minute, or until the paneer is heated through.
Step 8: Stir in the rose water or rose essence (if using).
Step 9: Serve the paneer kheer hot, warm, or chilled.

nutrition.sodium: Not specified, depends on the ingredients used such as paneer and nuts, can range from 50-100mg

recipes.name: Mango Kheer
ingredients: 1 kg ripe mangoes, peeled and pureed
2 tablespoons chopped nuts (almonds, cashews, or pistachios)
directions: Step 1: In a deep pan, combine the mango puree and 1/2 cup of water. Cook over medium heat until it comes to a gentle simmer.
Step 2: In a separate saucepan, prepare a sugar syrup by combining the sugar and a little water (about 1/4 cup). Boil until the syrup slightly thickens.
Step 3: Gradually add the sugar syrup to the mango mixture, stirring continuously to prevent lumps.

Step 4: Add the milk to the mango mixture. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the kheer thickens to your desired consistency (about 20-25 minutes).
Step 5: Remove from heat and allow to cool slightly. Garnish with chopped nuts before serving chilled.

recipes.name: Vermicelli Kheer
ingredients: 30 grams vermicelli, broken into smaller pieces
directions: Step 1: In a small bowl, combine the saffron threads with 2 tablespoons of warm water and let it bloom for about 10 minutes.
Step 2: In a heavy-bottomed saucepan, heat the skim milk over medium heat. Bring the milk to a gentle simmer.
Step 3: Add the broken vermicelli and rice powder to the simmering milk. Stir well to prevent lumps from forming.
Step 4: Reduce the heat to low and continue to cook the kheer for 15-20 minutes, or until the vermicelli is soft and the mixture has thickened slightly. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.
Step 5: Add the sugar and crushed cardamom pods to the kheer. Stir well and cook for another 5 minutes, allowing the sugar to dissolve and the flavors to meld.
Step 6: Remove the kheer from the heat and stir in the bloomed saffron.  Stir gently to distribute the color and flavor evenly.
Step 7: Garnish with the chopped pistachios.
Step 8: Serve the kheer warm or chilled.

directions: Step 1: In a large saucepan, combine the coconut milk, whole milk, and sugar. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat.

If desired, add a pinch of saffron strands to the milk mixture for color and flavor.
Garnish with other toppings such as chopped dates, cashews, or a sprinkle of ground cinnamon.

recipes.name: Classic Kheer (Indian Rice Pudding)
ingredients: 100 g Basmati rice, rinsed and drained
directions: Step 1: Rinse the basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain and set aside.
Step 2: In a large pot or saucepan, bring the whole milk to a boil over medium heat.
Step 3: Add the rinsed rice to the boiling milk and reduce the heat to low. Simmer for 10-15 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the rice is softened.
Step 4: Bring the mixture back to a boil twice, stirring constantly to prevent sticking.
Step 5: Reduce the heat to low again and check the rice for tenderness. It should be soft and cooked through.
Step 6: Stir in the cardamom powder.
Step 7: Gently stir in the sweetened condensed milk, ensuring the heat is low to prevent scorching. Cook for another 5-7 minutes, stirring continuously, until the kheer thickens slightly.
Step 8: The kheer should reach a consistency similar to thin porridge. Adjust cooking time as needed for desired consistency.
Step 9: Remove the kheer from the heat and transfer it to a serving bowl.
Step 10: Garnish with chopped pistachios or almonds.
Step 11: Allow the kheer to cool to room temperature before covering and refrigerating.
Step 12: Serve chilled.

recipes.name: Healthy Quinoa Apple Kheer
directions: Step 1: In a pot or saucepan, heat the ghee over medium heat. Add the finely chopped apple and sauté for 3-4 minutes, until slightly softened.
Step 2: Add the cooked quinoa, skim milk, saffron strands, and crushed cardamom to the pot. Stir well to combine.

Step 3: Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer for 35-40 minutes, or until the milk has reduced by about one-third and the kheer has thickened. Simmer for longer if you prefer a thicker consistency.
Step 4: Add the sugar and stir until it dissolves completely.
Step 5: Remove the kheer from the heat and let it cool to room temperature. Once cooled, refrigerate for at least 1 hour to chill thoroughly.
Step 6: Serve the chilled kheer in bowls, garnished with chopped pistachios and apple slices.

recipes.name: Jackfruit and Jaggery Kheer
ingredients: 12 medium Jackfruit, cut into equal square shaped slices
directions: Step 1: Heat 2 tablespoons of ghee in a wok or large pan over medium heat.
Step 2: Add the sliced jackfruit and fry for 7-8 minutes until slightly softened.
Step 3: In a blender or food processor, combine the grated coconut, jaggery powder, and 2 cups of water. Blend until a smooth paste forms.
Step 4: Transfer the coconut-jaggery mixture to a saucepan and bring to a boil. Reduce heat and simmer for 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Step 5: Add the fried jackfruit to the simmering jaggery mixture. Continue to simmer for another 2 minutes.
Step 6: In a separate saucepan, heat the milk until lukewarm. Do not boil.
Step 7: Heat the remaining 1 tablespoon of ghee in a small pan over medium heat. Add the cashews and sliced coconut and fry until golden brown.
Step 8: Add the lukewarm milk, cardamom powder, and fried cashews and coconut to the jackfruit-jaggery mixture. Stir well to combine.
Step 9: If desired, add more warm milk to adjust the consistency.
Step 10: Serve the kheer warm or chilled.

recipes.name: Slow Cooker Brown Rice Kheer with Jaggery
ingredients: 1/2 cup chopped nuts (cashews, almonds, and pistachios)
directions: Step 1: Rinse the brown rice under cold running water a few times. Coat the bottom and sides of the slow cooker pot with 1 teaspoon of melted ghee.
Step 2: Add the rinsed rice, milk, jaggery, and cardamom powder to the slow cooker. Stir to combine.
Step 3: Cover and cook on HIGH for 4 hours or on LOW for 8 hours.

Step 4: Open the lid and stir in the remaining 1 teaspoon of ghee, chopped nuts, and golden raisins. Cook for another 20-30 minutes with the lid slightly ajar if you prefer a thicker kheer. Otherwise, serve immediately. The kheer will thicken further as it cools.
Step 5: Serve hot, warm, or cold, garnished with additional chopped nuts and dried rose petals (if using).

recipes.name: Classic Indian Kheer (Rice Pudding)
ingredients: 1¼ cups sugar or ½ cup honey
directions: Step 1: Rinse the basmati rice under cold water until the water runs clear.  In a medium saucepan, combine the rinsed rice and 2 cups of water. Bring to a boil over medium heat, then reduce heat and simmer for 5-6 minutes, or until the rice is partially cooked (about one-quarter done). Drain the rice in a fine-mesh sieve and set aside.
Step 2: In a clean saucepan or pot, combine the almond milk and green cardamom pods. Bring the mixture to a gentle boil over medium heat.

Step 3: Add the par-cooked rice to the boiling almond milk. Reduce the heat to low, cover, and simmer for 30-40 minutes, or until the rice is very soft and the almond milk has thickened considerably. Stir occasionally at first, then more frequently as the mixture thickens to prevent sticking.

Step 4: Once the rice is cooked and the pudding has thickened, stir in the sugar (or honey for a vegan option), blanched slivered almonds, ground cardamom, and ground nutmeg. Continue to cook and stir for another 5 minutes, ensuring the sugar (or honey) is fully dissolved and the spices are well incorporated.
Step 5: Remove the kheer from the heat and let it cool slightly. Stir in the rose water. Taste and add more rose water, if desired. Serve warm or chilled in individual dessert bowls.

recipes.name: Phool Makhana Kheer (Lotus Seed Pudding)
directions: Step 1: Heat the ghee in a pan over medium heat. Add the chopped cashews and fry until golden brown. Remove the cashews from the pan and set aside.
Step 2: In the same pan, add the chopped fox nuts and fry for 2-3 minutes until lightly toasted.
Step 3: Pour in the milk and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 5 minutes.
Step 4: In a small bowl, soak the saffron strands in 2 tablespoons of warm milk for about 10 minutes. Gently crush the saffron strands to release their color and flavor.
Step 5: Add the sugar, saffron milk, and cardamom powder to the simmering milk and fox nut mixture. Continue to cook for 8-10 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the kheer thickens slightly.
Step 6: Stir in the fried cashews and remove from heat.
Step 7: Serve the Phool Makhana Kheer warm or chilled.

scenes.image_prompt: Milk being poured into the pan with roasted fox nuts. The mixture is about to be boiled on a stove.
scenes.voice_over: Pour in the two cups of milk and bring the mixture to a boil. Then reduce the heat to low and let it simmer for 5 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Saffron strands soaking in a small bowl of warm milk. The milk turns slightly yellow as the saffron color is released.
scenes.voice_over: Meanwhile, soak the saffron strands in two tablespoons of warm milk for 10 minutes. Gently crush the strands to release their color and aroma. This saffron milk will add a beautiful golden hue and a unique flavor to our kheer.

scenes.image_prompt: Sugar, saffron milk, and cardamom powder being added to the simmering milk and fox nuts mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Add the sugar, saffron milk, and a quarter teaspoon of cardamom powder to the simmering milk and fox nut mixture. Stir well and continue to cook for 8-10 minutes on low heat, stirring occasionally, until the kheer thickens slightly.

scenes.image_prompt: Fried cashews being stirred into the thickened kheer.
scenes.voice_over: Now, stir in the fried cashews and remove the pan from the heat.

scenes.image_prompt: Two bowls of Phool Makhana Kheer: one served warm and garnished with cashews and saffron, the other chilled and garnished similarly. A spoon is placed next to each bowl.
scenes.voice_over: Your Phool Makhana Kheer is ready! Serve it warm or chilled, as you prefer. It's a delightful dessert or a light and healthy snack. Each serving contains approximately 200 calories, 5 grams of protein, 30 grams of carbs, and 8 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use full-fat milk.
Adjust the amount of sugar according to your preference.
If you don't have saffron, you can use a pinch of turmeric powder for color.
Garnish with chopped pistachios or almonds before serving.

recipes.name: Jhangora Kheer (Millet Pudding)
ingredients: 2 tablespoons kewra essence or 2 tablespoons rose water
directions: Step 1: In a thick-bottomed pan, bring the milk to a boil.
Step 2: Add the jhangora to the boiling milk and stir continuously to prevent lumps.
Step 3: Reduce the heat to medium and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until the jhangora is tender and the mixture has thickened (approximately 20-25 minutes).
Step 4: Add the sugar and stir until it is completely dissolved.
Step 5: Continue cooking for another 5-7 minutes, or until the kheer reaches your desired consistency.
Step 6: Remove from heat and stir in the kewra essence or rose water.
Step 7: Garnish with the chopped cashews, raisins, and almonds.
Step 8: Refrigerate for at least 2 hours before serving. Serve chilled.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a bowl of Jhangora Kheer, garnished with chopped cashews, almonds, and raisins, against a rustic wooden background. Use soft, diffused natural light to highlight the creamy texture and warm tones of the pudding.  Employ a slightly overhead angle, focusing on the center of the bowl with a shallow depth of field to blur the background.  Incorporate a vintage silver spoon and a linen napkin for added visual interest. Create a warm, inviting mood that conveys comfort and indulgence.  Style the kheer to showcase its thick, creamy consistency and subtly glistening surface.

video_script.title: Jhangora Kheer: Creamy Millet Pudding
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and healthy Jhangora Kheer, a creamy millet pudding, with this easy-to-follow recipe.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a bowl of chilled Jhangora Kheer, garnished with chopped nuts and raisins. The pudding looks creamy and inviting.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making Jhangora Kheer, a delightful and nutritious Indian dessert. It's creamy, subtly sweet, and perfect for any occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of all ingredients arranged neatly on a wooden surface: barnyard millet, milk, sugar, cashews, raisins, almonds, and kewra essence.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: barnyard millet, whole milk, sugar, chopped cashews, raisins, almonds, and kewra essence for that aromatic touch.

scenes.image_prompt: A thick-bottomed pan with milk coming to a rolling boil on a stovetop.
scenes.voice_over: In a thick-bottomed pan, bring two quarts of whole milk to a boil.

scenes.image_prompt: The boiling milk in the pan, with barnyard millet being slowly added while stirring.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add two cups of barnyard millet to the boiling milk. Stir continuously to prevent lumps from forming.

scenes.image_prompt: The pan with milk and millet simmering on medium heat, being stirred occasionally. Steam is gently rising from the pan.
scenes.voice_over: Reduce the heat to medium and continue to cook for 20-25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the millet is tender and the mixture thickens.

scenes.image_prompt: Sugar being added to the simmering jhangora and milk mixture and stirred in until dissolved.
scenes.voice_over: Add 3/4 cup of sugar and stir until it dissolves completely.

scenes.image_prompt: The kheer simmering gently for a few more minutes after sugar has been added, the consistency becoming thicker.
scenes.voice_over: Continue cooking for another 5-7 minutes to achieve your desired consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: Kewra essence being stirred into the cooked kheer after it has been removed from the heat.
scenes.voice_over: Remove from the heat and stir in two tablespoons of kewra essence or rose water.

scenes.image_prompt: Chopped cashews, raisins, and almonds being sprinkled over the kheer.
scenes.voice_over: Garnish generously with chopped cashews, raisins, and almonds.

scenes.image_prompt: Two bowls of chilled Jhangora Kheer garnished with nuts and raisins, served with spoons on a table.
scenes.voice_over: Refrigerate for at least two hours before serving. Enjoy your chilled Jhangora Kheer! It has approximately 250 calories, 5 grams of protein, 45 grams of carbs, and 8 grams of fat per serving.

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, roast the jhangora lightly before cooking.
Adjust the amount of sugar according to your preference.
If the kheer becomes too thick, add a little warm milk to adjust the consistency.
You can also add other dried fruits and nuts, such as pistachios or chopped dates.

recipes.name: Fruit Kheer (Indian Fruit and Yogurt Pudding)
directions: Step 1: In a bowl, combine the sugar, black pepper, chili powder, salt, and yogurt. Mix well.
Step 2: Add the sliced bananas and orange segments to the yogurt mixture.
Step 3: Gently fold the fruit into the yogurt mixture for about 2 minutes.
Step 4: In a small bowl, dissolve the saffron strands in 1 teaspoon of water.
Step 5: Just before serving, sprinkle the saffron water over the kheer.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a vibrant Fruit Kheer in a shallow, white ceramic bowl.  Style with a few strategically placed orange segments and banana slices on the surface and a light dusting of saffron strands. Use a dark, slightly textured background to create contrast. Soft, diffused natural light from the side should highlight the creamy texture and vibrant colors.  Shallow depth of field with focus on the fruit and a slightly overhead angle will showcase the kheer's inviting texture.  Aim for a bright, fresh, and appetizing mood.

video_script.title: Refreshing Fruit Kheer: A Simple Indian Dessert
video_script.description: Learn how to make this quick and easy Fruit Kheer with simple ingredients in under 10 minutes. This creamy and flavorful Indian dessert is perfect for any occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a beautifully garnished bowl of Fruit Kheer, showcasing the vibrant colors of the fruits and the creamy texture of the yogurt.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making a delicious and refreshing Fruit Kheer, a classic Indian dessert that's perfect for a light treat. It’s creamy, fruity and comes together in minutes!

scenes.image_prompt: Display the grouped ingredients: yogurt in a bowl, bananas and oranges beside it, a small bowl with spices (sugar, pepper, chili powder, salt), and saffron strands with a teaspoon of water.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: plain yogurt, fresh bananas, juicy oranges, some basic spices – sugar, black pepper, chili powder, and salt – and a touch of saffron for that beautiful golden hue and aroma.

scenes.image_prompt: Show a bowl with sugar, pepper, chili powder, salt, and yogurt being mixed together.
scenes.voice_over: In a bowl, combine the sugar, black pepper, chili powder, salt, and yogurt. Mix thoroughly until well combined. This spice blend adds a unique depth of flavor to our kheer.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the sliced bananas and orange segments being added to the yogurt mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Now, add the sliced bananas and orange segments to the yogurt mixture. These fruits add a naturally sweet and tangy flavor, enhancing the creaminess of the kheer.”

scenes.image_prompt: Show the process of gently folding the fruits into the yogurt mixture.
scenes.voice_over: Gently fold the fruit into the yogurt mixture for about 2 minutes. Be careful not to overmix, as we want to maintain the shape of the fruit pieces.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up of saffron strands being dissolved in water in a small bowl.
scenes.voice_over: In a small bowl, dissolve the saffron strands in a teaspoon of water.  Saffron adds a beautiful color and a distinct flavor.  Let it sit for a few minutes to allow the color and aroma to develop.

scenes.image_prompt: Show saffron water being drizzled over the fruit kheer.
scenes.voice_over: Just before serving, sprinkle the saffron water over the kheer. This adds a touch of elegance and a warm, aromatic flavor.

scenes.image_prompt: Show the finished Fruit Kheer in a serving bowl, garnished with a few saffron strands and maybe a mint sprig. Show serving spoons.
scenes.voice_over: And there you have it – a refreshing and flavorful Fruit Kheer, ready to be enjoyed! You can serve it chilled for an extra refreshing treat. It’s about 200 calories per serving, with 5 grams of protein, 40 grams of carbs, and 5 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a sweeter kheer, add a touch of honey or maple syrup.
If you don't have fresh oranges, you can use canned mandarin oranges, drained.
Chill the kheer for at least 30 minutes before serving for a refreshing treat.
Garnish with chopped nuts like pistachios or almonds for added flavor and texture.

recipes.name: Vegan Chia Seed Pudding (Indian Kheer)
ingredients: 2 cups coconut milk (carton, not canned) or almond milk
2-4 tablespoons liquid sweetener (e.g., coconut nectar, agave, maple syrup)
3 tablespoons raw almonds, soaked for 8-12 hours
directions: Step 1: Heat 2 tablespoons of coconut milk in a small saucepan. Add the saffron strands and let them steep for a few minutes to release their color and flavor.

Step 2: In a mixing bowl, combine the remaining coconut milk (or almond milk), chia seeds, liquid sweetener, ground cardamom, and the saffron-infused milk. Stir well to ensure all ingredients are evenly distributed.
Step 3: Refrigerate the mixture for at least 4-6 hours, or preferably overnight, to allow the chia seeds to absorb the liquid and create a pudding-like consistency.
Step 4: Remove the pudding from the refrigerator and stir well to break up any lumps.
Step 5: Roughly chop the soaked almonds and pistachios.
Step 6: Transfer the chia pudding to individual serving bowls. Top with the chopped almonds, pistachios, raisins (if using), currants (if using), and coconut flakes.
Step 7: Serve chilled and enjoy!
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a styled shot of Vegan Chia Seed Pudding (Indian Kheer) in a shallow, rustic ceramic bowl.  Use soft, diffused natural light from the side to highlight the creamy texture and the vibrant colors of the saffron-infused pudding.  Garnish with slivered almonds, pistachios, a sprinkle of coconut flakes, and a few saffron strands.  Focus on the pudding's texture with a shallow depth of field, blurring the background slightly. Incorporate a textured linen napkin and a vintage spoon as props.  The overall mood should be bright, inviting, and slightly rustic.

video_script.title: Vegan Chia Seed Pudding (Indian Kheer)
video_script.description: A creamy and delicious vegan take on traditional Indian Kheer, made with chia seeds, coconut milk, and warming spices.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a beautifully styled bowl of vegan chia seed pudding, garnished with chopped almonds, pistachios, and coconut flakes. The pudding looks creamy and inviting.
scenes.voice_over: Welcome! Today, we're making a healthy and delicious vegan chia seed pudding inspired by Indian Kheer. It's creamy, flavorful, and perfect for a light dessert or breakfast.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of all the ingredients neatly arranged on a wooden table: coconut milk, chia seeds, saffron, sweetener, cardamom, almonds, pistachios, raisins, currants, and coconut flakes.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: coconut milk, chia seeds, saffron, your preferred liquid sweetener, ground cardamom, almonds, pistachios, and for extra flavor, some raisins, currants, and coconut flakes.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of saffron strands being steeped in warm coconut milk in a small saucepan. The milk is turning a beautiful golden yellow color.
scenes.voice_over: First, we'll infuse our coconut milk with saffron. Heat two tablespoons of coconut milk in a saucepan, add the saffron, and let it steep for a few minutes to release its color and aroma.

scenes.image_prompt: A mixing bowl with coconut milk, chia seeds, sweetener, cardamom, and the saffron-infused milk being whisked together. Show a close-up of the mixture being thoroughly combined.
scenes.voice_over: In a mixing bowl, combine the remaining coconut milk, chia seeds, sweetener, cardamom, and the saffron-infused milk. Mix well to ensure everything is evenly distributed.

scenes.image_prompt: The mixing bowl covered with plastic wrap being placed in a refrigerator. Time-lapse effect showing the chia pudding thickening over several hours.
scenes.voice_over: Cover the bowl and refrigerate for at least 4-6 hours, or preferably overnight. This allows the chia seeds to absorb the liquid and create that perfect pudding-like consistency.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of chopped almonds and pistachios on a cutting board.
scenes.voice_over: While the pudding chills, roughly chop the soaked almonds and pistachios.

scenes.image_prompt: Chia seed pudding being scooped into serving bowls and topped with chopped almonds, pistachios, raisins, currants, and coconut flakes.
scenes.voice_over: Once the pudding has set, give it a good stir. Now, transfer to serving bowls and garnish with the chopped almonds, pistachios, raisins, currants, and coconut flakes.

scenes.image_prompt: Final shot of two beautifully styled bowls of vegan chia seed pudding, garnished with various toppings, with spoons placed next to them. Some extra toppings in small bowls around the pudding.
scenes.voice_over: Your delicious and healthy Vegan Chia Seed Pudding is ready! It's a fantastic treat that’s packed with flavor and nutrients. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use full-fat coconut milk.
Adjust the amount of sweetener to your preference.
If you don't have coconut nectar or agave, maple syrup or honey can be used as alternatives.
Soaking the almonds enhances their flavor and makes them easier to digest.
Toasting the nuts before adding them to the pudding adds an extra layer of flavor and crunch.

recipes.name: Slow Cooker Kheer (Indian Rice Pudding)
directions: Step 1: In your slow cooker, whisk together the whole milk, uncooked basmati rice, sweetened condensed milk, golden raisins, slivered almonds, and ground cardamom.
Step 2: Cover the slow cooker and cook on low for 3 1/2 to 4 hours.
Step 3: Check the kheer after 3 1/2 hours. It's ready when it has thickened to a pudding-like consistency.
Step 4: Serve warm, hot, at room temperature, or chilled.
recipes.image_prompt: Capture a close-up, slightly overhead shot of Slow Cooker Kheer in a rustic, earthenware bowl, nestled on a dark wood surface. Soft, diffused natural light from the side should highlight the creamy texture and golden hues of the rice pudding.  Garnish with a few extra golden raisins, slivered almonds, and a dusting of cardamom.  Shallow depth of field, focusing on the foreground kheer, with the background softly blurred. Create a warm, inviting, and comforting mood.

video_script.title: Slow Cooker Kheer: Creamy Indian Rice Pudding
video_script.description: Learn how to make delicious and creamy Kheer in your slow cooker. This easy recipe requires minimal effort and delivers a comforting, flavorful dessert.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a bowl of creamy, perfectly cooked kheer garnished with slivered almonds and golden raisins. The background is slightly blurred, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere.
scenes.voice_over: Indulge in the rich and creamy goodness of slow cooker kheer. This classic Indian rice pudding is incredibly easy to make and perfect for any occasion.

scenes.image_prompt: Overhead shot of all the ingredients neatly arranged on a wooden table: whole milk in a jug, uncooked basmati rice in a bowl, sweetened condensed milk in a can, golden raisins and slivered almonds in small bowls, and ground cardamom in a spice jar.
scenes.voice_over: Here's what you'll need: whole milk, basmati rice, sweetened condensed milk, golden raisins, slivered almonds, and ground cardamom for that aromatic warmth.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of a person whisking together the milk, rice, condensed milk, raisins, almonds, and cardamom in a slow cooker.
scenes.voice_over: In your slow cooker, whisk together the milk, uncooked rice, sweetened condensed milk, raisins, almonds, and cardamom. Ensure everything is well combined.

scenes.image_prompt: A slow cooker with its lid on, cooking the kheer. A timer is displayed next to the slow cooker, showing 3 1/2 to 4 hours.
scenes.voice_over: Cover the slow cooker and cook on low for 3 1/2 to 4 hours. The low and slow cooking allows the rice to soften and the flavors to meld beautifully.

scenes.image_prompt: A person opening the lid of the slow cooker and checking the consistency of the kheer with a spoon.
scenes.voice_over: After 3 1/2 hours, check the kheer. It's ready when it has thickened to a pudding-like consistency. If needed, cook for another 30 minutes.

scenes.image_prompt: Close-up shot of bowls filled with warm kheer, garnished with extra almonds and raisins. Some bowls are steaming, while others are at room temperature or chilled. Various serving suggestions like fresh fruit are also displayed.
scenes.voice_over: Serve your kheer warm, hot, at room temperature, or even chilled.  It's delicious on its own or with fresh fruit. Your creamy, dreamy slow cooker kheer is ready!

scenes.image_prompt: Text overlay displaying nutrition information: Calories: 250, Protein: 5g, Carbs: 45g, Fat: 7g. Background image of a person enjoying a bowl of kheer.
scenes.voice_over: Per serving, this delightful dessert has approximately 250 calories, 5 grams of protein, 45 grams of carbs, and 7 grams of fat. Enjoy!

cooking_tips: For a richer flavor, use full-fat milk.
If the kheer becomes too thick, you can stir in a little extra milk to reach your desired consistency.
Garnish with chopped nuts or a sprinkle of cardamom before serving.
